content.description: Originally named "Zivas Book" in the 1987 Rocky Butte Quarry guidebook. An interesting steep corner climb with balance moves
content.protection: Chain Anchors at the top. 3 bolts - 1st bolt is pretty high up.  Also a good tree 7 feet back from the ledge
content.location: If you are at the obvious Flakey Old Man, just to the left you you should see the bolts on Bikini that goes straight up the rounded buttress. It goes up into the left of the butress, topping out in the obvious indentation. There are some obvious chain anchors you can use or there is a tree about 7 feet back you can use for an anchor

content.description: Work the vertical face to the right of the dihedral. Stained Glass is the corner of that same dihedral, so avoid the corner
content.protection: Tree anchor from a tree quite far away
content.location: From the bottom, look for the first prow to the right of Flakey Old Man. From the top, look for the small tree to the left of the Flakey Old Man ramp. That is basically at the Panes of Reality anchors, so look for the corner just to the left of the anchors

climbs.name: Stranger Than Friction
climbs.fa: FFA: May 29, 1987 by Tim Olson & Bob McGown

content.description: This route is the bolted line to the right of Flakey Old Man. It starts with two small pockets, followed by a big move to a sloping ledge. Adequate feet support good hands. This route is super dirty in the early part of the season.
content.protection: 5 quickdraws, and not a bad idea to stick clip the first bolt. The crux is probably the first move, and the landing isn't nice. Can be toproped easily enough.
content.location: On the northern section of Video Bluff, to the right of Flakey Old Man.

content.description: Dihedral corner. Always bring a brush. Rain brings a coat of dirt on almost all of Video Bluff.
The crux seems to be moving off the slope and getting into the corner.
content.protection: Anchors at top, keep it short to protect the top of the climb.

content.description: Left of Stained Glass, Crux is the bulge right after the start. Starting point is a boulder on the ground in front of a tree
content.protection: Use the tree on the ledge as anchor
content.location: Between Stranger than Friction and Stained Glass

content.description: Climb the middle face of a slab with thin edges which leads onto a flat ledge. From here, make your way to the crack to the right of the arete. Though the crack starts thin, it flares open enough for full hands or an arm. Work the face or the arete for some variation, either option is still at the same grade. Fairly sustained at the grade with a variety of climbing styles.The anchors here appeared thanks to some mysterious benefactor in the Covid Summer of 2020. Previously, a lot of dead tree brush existed here. Despite attempts, the bolter has not been identified since and still owes it a name.
content.protection: Anchors with rap rings. From the top, the leftmost ones work well
content.location: From Flakey Old Man, look just left for a small outcropping of rocks jutting out. You can step down from the top onto a rocky ledge. This ledge holds 3 sets of chain anchors right below the lip, on the face of the climbs, making for left, middle and right anchors. The left set will work best for this route. You can rap down to a flat lower ledge if you just want to complete just the crack portion and rap further down the slab to complete the entire route.Alternatively, you can use the Eastward downclimb to get to the base, then keep walking past EZ Corner and around the corner to get to the base of the climb. There is a sketchy gap around that corner if you are going to take this route!

content.description: Rounded face (almost a corner) with small slopers all the way up. Bolted route, easy to find.
content.location: Starts about 6 feet to the right of Eve of Destruction.

climbs.name: Lever or Leaver
climbs.fa: G. Rall, Mike Pajunas, John Sprecher, August 1987

content.description: A steep slab climb on thin edges leads into a shallow dihedral for just a few moves until the top ledge. You can exit to the right of the anchors.Often dirty and could use a good scrub at the start of each Spring
content.protection: 4 Bolts. Chain Anchors at the top
content.location: From Flakey Old Man, there is a prow on the left. Look one whole prow to the left of that. On the left side of that prow you should see a line of 4 bolts and a set of anchors at the top

content.description: This is a classic problem. It isn't hard, but can be really enjoyable, especially for newbies or first-time sport leaders. The most interesting move is near the top, where you must switch hands to the flakey stuff on the left.
content.protection: Bolts. 2-bolt Anchor at the top. Use a tree and a long sling to safely get to the top-rope bolts. Or, lead it, which is more fun.
content.location: Just about dead-center in the wall. Right of a 5.10 on a nose and Left of a difficult looking 5.11.

content.description:
Easy way to get out without hiking around.   

  Really EZ
content.protection: Make an anchor on horizontal trees at top and rap down.

content.description: Sloping dihedral, inside corner crack. Somewhat dirty, doesn't seem to get climbed very often.
content.protection: Small to medium pro or TR from bolted anchor.
content.location: Farthest left route on Video Bluff. Inside corner left of the bolted Live Wire route.

content.description: This is the route just to the right of Robotics that starts on the slab. Clip the first two bolts then angle slightly right to the arête which is used repeatedly for slapping. Several good rests allow for recovery and contemplation.Edge of Might is one of the least physical 5.11's you will encounter around Portland. Balance and good footwork are key to making progress. EoM is likely the best route on the Video Bluff. Unfortunately, water seeps down this climb, making non-summer ascents hard to come by.
content.protection: Fully bolted with an old chain anchor at the top.
content.location: Starts just to the right of Robotics.

content.description: Challenging stem problem up a shallow scoop. Begin up a shattered start, pull a thin move to an awkward stance, then smear, stem of a face using strange finger holds in the seam.
The crux is just past the second bolt, a balancey left-hand friction move to a good ledge.  There are balance moves and power moves, a well rounded route.
content.location: This route follows the bolt line up the buttress to the left of Flakey Old Man, with which it shares a start (and first bolt).

content.protection: There are bolts at the for you or you could throw in some trad gear.  Small rack should do fine.
content.location: Two crack system with an obvious tree half way up on the southerly end of the bluff.

content.description: Probably the most popular wall at the Butte. Rock is basalt and is a bit slick - especially early or late climbing season. This is a short 30-40ft wall, which has about a dozen routes, all of which can be top-roped. There are couple sport-leads too.
